0.title: CHILDREN CALL ME MOTHER GOOSE
0.rhyme:
Old mother goose, when
She wanted to wander,
Would ride through the air
On a very fine gander.
questions: Mother Goose would ride on a very fine what?
The rhyme says Mother Goose was what?
Mother Goose liked to ride through the what?
Mother Goose sometimes wanted to do what?
What sound comes at the very beginning of "wanted" and "wander"?

1.title: LADY-BIRD LADY-BIRD
1.rhyme:
Lady-bird, Lady-bird,
Fly away home,
Your house is on fire,
Your children alone.
questions: Her house is on what?
Her children are what?
Probably the lady-bird feels what?
How should the lady-bird get home?
What sound comes in the middle of "Lady-bird" and at the beginning of "burn"?

2.title: JACK SPRAT WOULD EAT NO FAT
2.rhyme:
Jack Sprat would eat no fat,
His wife would eat no lean;
And so between the two of them
They licked the platter clean.
questions: What was the first name of the man named Sprat?
The man would eat no what?
His what would eat no lean?
The two of them did what to get the platter clean?

3.title: LITTLE JACK HORNER
3.rhyme:
Little Jack Horner
Sat in a corner
Eating a Christmas pie;
He put in his thumb,
And pulled out a plum,
And said: "What a good boy am I!"
questions: What did the little boy do in a corner?
The little boy put his thumb in a what?
The little boy pulled out a what?
The little boy was named what?
What sounds come at the end of "thumb" and "plum"?

4.title: LITTLE TOM TUCKER
4.rhyme:
Little Tom Tucker
Sings for his supper.
What shall he eat?
White bread and butter.
How will he cut it
Without any a knife?
How will he marry
Without any wife?
questions: The little boy's name is what?
The little boy sings for what?
What color bread does the boy eat?
What does the boy eat with the bread?
What sound comes in the middle of "knife" and "wife"?

5.title: HERE AM I, LITTLE JUMPING JOAN
5.rhyme:
Here am I, little jumping Joan,
When nobody’s with me
I’m always alone.

What sound comes at the beginning and end of "little" and in the middle of "alone"?

6.title: LITTLE BO PEEP
6.rhyme:
Little Bo-peep has lost her sheep,
And doesn’t know where to find them;
Leave them alone, and they’ll come home,
Wagging their tails behind them.

The rhyme says the animals will come where?

questions: The first little piggy went where?

8.title: I LIKE LITTLE KITTY, HER COAT IS SO WARM
8.rhyme:
I like little kitty, her coat is so warm,
And if I don’t hurt her she’ll do me no harm;
So I’ll not pull her tail, nor drive her away,
But kitty and I very gently will play.
questions: What does little kitty have that is so warm?
The person speaking will not pull kitty’s what?

warm
 and

?

9.title: OLD KING COLE
9.rhyme:
Old King Cole
Was a merry old soul,
And a merry old soul was he;
He called for his pipe,
And he called for his bowl,
And he called for his fiddlers three.
questions: Old King Cole was what kind of an old soul?
Old King Cole first called for his what?
The second thing Old King Cole called for was his what?

10.title: HIGH DIDDLE DIDDLE
10.rhyme:
High diddle diddle,
The cat and the fiddle,
The cow jumped over the moon;
The little dog laughed
To see such sport,
And the dish ran away with the spoon.
questions: The cow jumped over the what?

11.title: BYE, BABY BUNTING
11.rhyme:
Bye, Baby Bunting,
Father’s gone a-hunting,
Mother’s gone a-milking,

12.title: ROCK-A-BYE, BABY, ON THE TREE TOP,
12.rhyme:

What will make the cradle rock?
The cradle will fall if the bough does what?

What sound comes at the beginning of "baby" and "bough"?

13.title: OLD MOTHER HUBBARD
13.rhyme:
Old Mother Hubbard
Went to the cupboard
To get her poor dog a bone;

14.title: PETER PETER PUMPKIN EATER 1
14.rhyme:
Peter, Peter, pumpkin eater,
Had a wife and couldn’t keep her;
He put her in a pumpkin shell,
And then he kept her very well.

15.title: MISTRESS MARY
15.rhyme:
Mistress Mary, quite contrary,
How does your garden grow?
With silver bells and cockle shells
And pretty maids all in a row.
questions: What is the name of the girl called mistress?
She is asked how her what grows?
What color are the bells?

16.title: DING-DONG-BELL
16.rhyme:
Ding—dong—bell, Kitty’s in the well.
Who put her in? Little Johnny Green.
Who pulled her out? Little Johnny Stout.
What a naughty boy was that
To try to drown poor kitty cat
Who never did him any harm, 
And killed the mice in his father’s barn.
questions: Kitty was put in the what?
The boy who put her in was called Little Johnny what color?
What did kitty kill?

17.title: A DILLAR, A DOLLAR
17.rhyme:
A dillar, a dollar,
A ten o’clock scholar;
What makes you come so soon?
You used to come at ten o’clock,
But now you come at noon!
questions: What silly word comes before dollar?

18.title: LITTLE BOY BLUE
18.rhyme:
Little Boy Blue, come blow your horn,
The sheep’s in the meadow, the cow’s in the corn.
Where is the boy who minds the sheep?
Under the haystack fast asleep.
Will you wake him?  No, not I, 
For if I do he’s sure to cry.
questions: The little boy is described as what color?
The little boy is asked to blow a what?
What animal is in the meadow?
What animal is in the corn?
What sounds are at the beginning of "blue" and "blow"?

19.title: TOM, TOM, THE PIPER'S SON
19.rhyme:
Tom, Tom, the piper’s son,
Stole a pig, and away did run;
The pig was eat, 
And Tom was beat, 
And Tom ran crying down the street.
questions: Tom was the son of a what?
What did Tom steal?
After he stole, the rhyme says Tom was what?

20.title: JACK AND JILL
20.rhyme:
Jack and Jill went up the hill
To fetch a pail of water;
Jack fell down and broke his crown, 
And Jill came tumbling after.

21.title: LITTLE MISS MUFFET
21.rhyme:
Little Miss Muffet
Sat on a tuffet,
Eating some curds and whey.

22.title: JENNY WREN 1
22.rhyme:
Twas once upon a time, when Jenny Wren was young,
So daintily she danced and so prettily she sung,
Robin Redbreast lost his heart, for he was a gallant bird,
So he doffed his hat to Jenny Wren, requesting to be heard.
questions: Jenny was what kind of bird?
Jenny’s gallant friend was what kind of bird?
The gallant bird doffed his what to Jenny?

23.title: JENNY WREN 2
23.rhyme:
O, dearest Jenny Wren, if you will but be mine,
You shall feed on cherry pie and drink new apple wine,
I’ll dress you like a goldfinch or any peacock gay,
So, dearest Jen, if you’ll be mine let us decide today.
questions: Her friend says Jenny will drink what kind of wine?
Her friend says Jenny will eat cherry what?
Her friend says he’ll dress her like a goldfinch or any gay what?
Her friend asks her to decide on what day?
What sound comes at the beginning of "dearest" and "dress" and "decide"?

24.title: JENNY WREN 3
24.rhyme:
Jenny blushed behind her fan and thus declared her mind:
“Since, dearest Bob, I love you well, I’ll take your offer kind;
Cherry pie is very nice and so is apple wine,
But I must wear my plain brown gown and never go too fine.
questions: What name does Jenny call her dearest friend?
Jenny says she will wear a plain gown of what color?
Jenny blushed behind her what?
What sound comes in the middle of "blush" and "thus" and "love"?

25.title: HOW MANY DAYS HAS MY BABY TO PLAY?
25.rhyme:

26.title: LITTLE KING BOGGEN
26.rhyme:

27.title: AS I WENT TO BONNER

28.title: MISS JANE AND A MOUSE
28.rhyme:

29.title: THE QUEEN OF HEARTS 1
29.rhyme:
The Queen of Hearts,
She made some tarts

Who stole the tarts?

30.title: THE QUEEN OF HEARTS 2
30.rhyme:

Called for the tarts,
And beat the knave full sore;

Brought back the tarts,

31.title: DAFFY-DOWN-DILLY
31.rhyme:

32.title: I'VE LAID AN EGG
32.rhyme:
"Cock, cock, cock, cock,
I’ve laid an egg,
Am I to go ba-are-foot?"
"Hen, hen, hen, hen,
I've been up and down

33.title: THE LION AND THE UNICORN
33.rhyme:

34.title: BONNY LASS PRETTY LASS
34.rhyme:

35.title: HANDY-SPANDY JACKY DANDY
35.rhyme:

36.title: TWO LITTLE BLACKBIRDS
36.rhyme:
Two little blackbirds sitting on a hill,

37.rhyme:

38.title: POLLY PUT THE KETTLE ON
38.rhyme:
Polly, put the kettle on,
Polly, put the kettle on,

39.title: THE SOW CAME IN WITH THE SADDLE 1
39.rhyme:

40.title: THE SOW CAME IN WITH THE SADDLE 2
40.rhyme:
The spit that stood behind the door
Threw the pudding-stick on the floor.
"Gracious!" said the gridiron,
"Can't you agree?
I'm the boss policeman,
Bring them to me!"
questions: The spit stood behind the what?

41.title: LITTLE ROBIN REDBREAST 1
41.rhyme:
Little Robin Redbreast sat upon a tree,
Up went the Kitty-Cat, and down went he,
Down came Kitty-Cat, away Robin ran;

questions: The rhyme is about what kind of red-breasted bird?
The little bird sat upon a what?

42.title: LITTLE ROBIN REDBREAST 2
42.rhyme:
Little Robin Redbreast jumped upon a spade,
Kitty-Cat jumped after him, and then he was afraid.
Little Robin chirped and sang, and what did Kitty say?
Kitty-Cat said: “Meow, meow, meow,” and Robin flew away.
questions: Little Robin jumped upon a what?

43.title: A FARMER WENT TROTTING
43.rhyme:
A farmer went trotting upon his gray mare,
Bumpety, bumpety, bump,
With his daughter behind him, so rosy and fair,
Lumpety, lumpety, lump.
A blackbird cried “Croak,” and they all tumbled down,
Bumpety, bumpety, bump;
The mare broke her knees and the farmer his crown,
Lumpety, lumpety, lump.
The mischievous blackbird flew laughing away,
Bumpety, bumpety, bump,
And promised to do just the same next day!
Lumpety, lumpety, lump.
questions: The farmer rode on a mare horse what color?
Riding behind the farmer was his what?
What color bird cried "Croak" and flew away?
What word rhymes with "lump" and "bump"?
What sound is at the beginning of "bumpety" and "bump" and "blackbird"?

44.title: OLD WOMAN SOLD PUDDING AND PIES
44.rhyme:
There was an old woman
Sold puddings and pies;
She went to the hill,
And dust flew in her eyes.
While all through the streets,
To all that she meets
She always cries:
"Hot Pies—Hot Pies."
questions: The old woman sold puddings and what?
The old woman went to the what?
Dust flew in the old woman’s what?

What sounds are at the end of "dust" and beginning of "street"?

45.title: OLD WOMAN OLD WOMAN
45.rhyme:
"Old woman, old woman, shall we go a-shearing?"
"Speak a little louder, sir, I’m very hard of hearing."
"Old woman, old woman, shall I kiss you dearly?"
"Thank you, quite kindly sir, I hear very clearly."
questions: The woman says speak a little what sir?
The woman says she’s hard of what?
The man asks if he should do what to her dearly?

What sounds are at the beginning of "shall" and "shear"?

46.title: MY LITTLE OLD MAN AND I
46.rhyme:
My little old man and I had a spat;
Sit and I’ll tell you all about that:
I had money and he had none,
And that’s the way the noise begun.
questions: The woman had a spat with her little old what?
The old woman had what and he had none?

What sound is at the beginning of "out" and in the middle of "about"?

47.title: THERE WAS AN OLD WOMAN
47.rhyme:
There was an old woman, and what do you think?
She lived upon nothing but foods and drink;

questions: The rhyme says the woman is what?

48.title: WHAT'S THE NEW OF THE DAY
48.rhyme:

Has gone up to the moon.

49.title: THE MAN IN THE WILDERNESS
49.rhyme:
The man in the wilderness
Asked me
How many strawberries
Grew in the sea.
I answered him
As I thought good,
Just as many as red herrings
Grew in the wood.
questions: The man at the beginning was in the what?

50.title: HARK! HARK! THE DOGS DO BARK
50.rhyme:
Hark! Hark!
The dogs do bark,
The beggars are coming to town;

And one in a velvet gown.

51.title: GOING TO ST.IVES
51.rhyme:
As I was going to St. Ives
I met a man with seven wives.
Every wife had seven sacks,
Every sack had seven cats,
Every cat had seven kits.
Kits, cats, sacks and wives,
How many were going to St. Ives?
questions: The person speaking the rhyme was going where?
The man had how many wives?

52.title: I HAD A LITTLE HUSBAND
52.rhyme:
I had a little husband no bigger than my thumb,
I put him in a little pot, and had him play a drum;
I bought a little handkerchief to wipe his little nose,
And a pair of little garters to tie his little hose.
questions: The little husband was no bigger than a what?
The wife put her husband in a little what?

53.title: BIG A LITTLE A
53.rhyme:
Big A, little a,
Bouncing B;

But me she didn’t C.
questions: The first letter is a big what?
The bouncing letter is a what?
What is in the cupboard?

54.title: BAT BAT COME UNDER MY HAT
54.rhyme:
Bat, bat,
Come under my hat,
And I’ll give you a slice of bacon;
And when I bake
I’ll give you a cake,
If I am not mistaken.
questions: In the rhyme somebody speaks to what animal?

55.title: PRETTY GIRL OF PRIMROSE HILL
55.rhyme:
As I was going up Primrose Hill,
Primrose Hill was dirty;
There I met a pretty girl,
And she gave me a curtsey.

Blessings be upon you;

I’d spend it all on you.
questions: Primrose is the name of a what?

57.title: GOOD KING ARTHUR
57.rhyme:
When good King Arthur ruled his land
He was a goodly king;
He stole three sacks of barley meal
To make a bag-pudding.
A bag-pudding the king did make,
And stuffed it well with plums,
And in it put great lumps of fat
As big as my two thumbs.
The king and queen ate less than half,
Not much more, though they tried,
And what they could not eat that night
The queen next morning fried.

58.rhyme:
"Jacky, come give me your fiddle,
And you shall have pennies five."
"No, I'll not give my fiddle
To any man alive.
"If I should give my fiddle
They’ll think I’ve lost my mind,

60.rhyme:
The north wind does blow,
And we shall have snow,

Poor thing!

61.title: YOU OWE ME FIVE ONIONS
61.rhyme:
"You owe me five onions,"
Say the bells of St. Helen’s.
"When will you pay me?"
Say the bells of Old Bailey.
"When I grow rich,"
Say the bells of Shoreditch.
"When will that be?"
Say the bells of Stepney.
"I do not know,"
Says the great Bell of Bow.
"Two sticks in an apple,"
Ring the bells of Whitechapel.
"Orchards and garden,"
Say the bells of St. Martin’s.
"Kettles and pans,"
Say the bells of St. Ann’s.
"Shingles and tiles,"
Say the bells of St. Giles.
"Old shoes and slippers,"
Say the bells of St. Peter’s.
"Sleepy-time yawns,"
Say the bells of St. John’s.
questions: The bells of St. Helen’s say you owe five what that rhymes with Helen’s?
The bells of Whitechapel ring two sticks and a what that rhymes with chapel?

122.title: THERE WERE TWO BIRDS 1
122.rhyme:
There were two birds sat upon a stone,
Fal de ral-al de ral-laddy.
One flew away and then there was one,
Fal de ral-al de ral-laddy.
The other flew after and then there was none,
Fal de ral-al de ral-laddy.
So the poor stone was left all alone,
Fal de ral-al de ral-laddy.

123.title: THERE WERE TWO BIRDS 2
123.rhyme:
One of these little birds back again flew,
Fal de ral-al de ral-laddy.
The other came after and then there were two,
Fal de ral-al de ral-laddy.
Says one to the other: "Tell me, how do you do?"
Fal de ral-al de ral-laddy.
"Very well, thank you, and how are you?"
Fal de ral-al de ral-laddy.

127.title: FOUR-AND-TWENTY TAILORS
127.rhyme:

129.title: ROBIN AND RICHARD
129.rhyme:

131.title: I HAD A LITTLE HEN
131.rhyme:
